docs.lead_paragraph: IF any one piece of real estate in Connecticut best represents the history of the Industrial Revolution it would have to be a couple of acres on Capitol Avenue in Hartford near the state capitol. Starting in the mid-19th century, the factory buildings on the site were passed along from company to company. As one industry faded, or moved elsewhere, another came to take its place. On the site have been, in turn, a rifle manufacturing company (Sharps), a sewing machine company (Weed), a pioneer precision tool maker (Pratt & Whitney), the biggest high-wheel bicycle company in the world (Columbia), an early automobile plant (Pope-Hartford), an aircraft engine plant (Pratt & Whitney again) and, finally, as the 20th century was drawing to a close, a high-tech, computerized adjunct for an insurance company (Aetna).

docs.lead_paragraph: The class content of a Pat Buchanan rally is so thick you can smell it. It smells like motor oil. Or so it does this February afternoon on the floor of a transmission factory in Fort Dodge, Iowa, where the air tools hiss, the employees wear coveralls and Buchanan confers upon them the proud title "worker." He issues his usual condemnations of corporate greed and pokes fun at Steve Forbes, his impossibly rich rival, for cooking up his ideas with "the boys down at the yacht club." He even solicits Democratic votes by mocking his own party's plutocratic past. "You can join the party of greed for one evening!" But when I approach Buchanan and note, perhaps with a trace of grudging admiration, that he has brought a new class sensibility to the election, he blanches. Actually, he puckers. "Class sensibility?" he says, spitting out the phrase like a bad olive. Though Buchanan is rarely at a loss for words, this stops him cold. "I don't think I want to go anywhere near that one." Instead, he climbs back into his bus and resumes his underdog campaign, on behalf of those who "work with their hands and tools and machines."

headline.main: CLASS IS NO LONGER A FOUR-LETTER WORD

docs.lead_paragraph: Many days Tongris Situmorang, in his blue baseball hat with a large X on the front, hangs around the gates of the enormous Nike sport shoe factory here, talking to friends leaving the assembly lines at the end of the work day. The gangly 22-year-old used to work inside the well-guarded gates, but five months ago he was dismissed for organizing workers to demand more than the 4,600 rupiah they are paid each day, about $2.10, the Government-dictated minimum wage. Then, after being dismissed, he was locked in a room at the plant and interrogated for seven days by the military, which demanded to know more about his labor activities.

headline.main: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: An Indonesian Asset Is Also a Liability;Low Wages Woo Foreign Business, But the Price Is Worker Poverty

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In a startling reversal of priorities, this society is now beginning to reimburse veterinary care at rates equal to or higher than rates for medical care of its human citizens.

headline.main: Medical Care Is Going to the Dogs

docs.snippet: To the Editor:         In a startling reversal of priorities, this society is now beginning to reimburse veterinary care at rates equal to or higher than rates for medical care of its human citizens.

docs.lead_paragraph: One of the side trips of the Whitewater investigation is being played out in a Federal courtroom here as Gov. Jim Guy Tucker of Arkansas and two former business partners of President Clinton stand trial on conspiracy and fraud charges growing out of a separate series of bank loans and real estate transactions a decade ago. It is a historic trial in many ways. It is the first time that a sitting Arkansas governor has been on trial, presenting the curious picture of Mr. Tucker sitting idle, but intent, in a courtroom most of the day while spending early mornings, lunch and evening hours six blocks away at the Capitol trying to squeeze in the business of government.

headline.main: Major and Minor Players in Place, Historic Whitewater TrialUnderwhelms Little Rock

docs.lead_paragraph: With a bipartisan spirit rarely seen in Congress these days, a House subcommittee today approved legislation that would guarantee health insurance coverage for millions of Americans who change jobs or lose their jobs each year. The panel, the House Commerce Subcommittee on Health and the Environment, endorsed the bill by voice vote, with no audible dissent. The bill is part of a large package of health care legislation developed by House Republican leaders.

headline.main: A House Panel Supports a Bill On Health Care
